Editor's choice paper The effect of Fe2O3 promotion on the ammoxidation of o-xylene with V-Cr-based catalyst Yixin Lian Conceptualization Writing – review & editing Supervision ⁎ Xin Huang Methodology Writing – original draft Writing – review & editing Dongyu Liu Methodology Writing – review & editing Lihua Yu Methodology Writing – review & editing RenKe Yu Methodology Writing – review & editing Weijie Wang Methodology Writing – review & editing Wang Shuai Writing – review & editing Supervision College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, National Engineering Laboratory for Green Chemical Productions of Alcohols-Ethers-Esters, Xiamen University, Xiamen 361005, China College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering National Engineering Laboratory for Green Chemical Productions of Alcohols-Ethers-Esters Xiamen University Xiamen 361005 China College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, National Engineering Laboratory for Green Chemical Productions of Alcohols-Ethers-Esters, Xiamen University, Xiamen 361005, China ⁎ Corresponding author. A series of V-Cr-based catalysts with different Fe2O3 contents were prepared for o-xylene ammoxidation and their catalytic property was studied. The evaluation results showed that the appropriate Fe2O3 addition enhanced catalytic performance, and the best addition mass fraction was 0.5%. The conversion of o-xylene ammoxidation on the catalysts with different Fe2O3 contents increased from 53.8% to 94.7%, and the yield of the target product increased from 32.7% to 53.0%. It was found that the addition of Fe2O3 can change the physical properties and acid-base properties of the catalyst. An appropriate amount of Fe2O3 not only improved the amount of lattice oxygen vacancies in the catalyst and changed the adsorbed oxygen on the surface, but also adjusted the V +4 /V +5 ratio of active oxide V=O, which is conducive to the oxidation–reduction process, thus improving the performance of the catalyst. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords O-xylene Ammonia oxidation V-Cr based catalyst Redox property Data availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction The strong activity of the cyano group on the benzene ring of aromatic nitrile compound is easy to undergo reactions like oxidation, hydrolysis, hydrogenation, and polymerization. It is widely used in the synthesis of chemical materials and organic intermediates. Among them, the o-phthalonitrile (OPN) can be used in the synthesis of phthalocyanine pigments and dyes, phthalsulfanilamide drugs, photosensitive coatings, polymer stabilizers, high thermal resistance polyamide fiber, etc. [1–4]. The traditional synthesis methods of phthalonitrile mainly include the o-phenylenediamine Sandmeyer method, phthalic anhydride catalytic amination method, o-phthalimide ammoniation and dehydrating method, and o-dihalophenylcyanide substitution method, etc. The o-xylene gas phase ammoxidation method has the advantages of being green, environment-friendly, and large-scale, thus has become a research focus [5–9]. It is generally believed that o-xylene reacts with ammonia and air under the action of catalysts to produce tolunitrile, phthalonitrile, and phthalimide. The reaction formula is as follows [2]: But, Narayana et al., [2]after studying the ammoxidation of o-xylene, found that many factors during the reaction process would cause competitive reactions such as demethylation, hydrolysis, excessive oxidation, and ammonia oxidation. And a possible route map for the ammoxidation of o-xylene was proposed, as shown in Fig. 1 . The ammoxidation process obeyed the mechanism of Mars-Van Krevelene. Although there were differences between different catalysts in the ammoxidation process, the process of aromatic ammoxidation could be summarized as the following steps on the whole: (1) The aromatic was absorbed on the Lewis acid sites because of the π bonds. (2) The αH on the methyl group was dehydrated with lattice oxygen of vanadium oxide to form aldehyde intermediates. (3) Chemisorbed NH3 was inserted into the aromatics as an N source. (4) The product nitrile was desorbed on the surface of the catalysts, resulting in the formation of oxygen vacancies. (5) Lattice oxygen was regenerated under oxygen conditions [10]. Generally, aromatics ammoxidation catalysts are mainly composed of acid oxides and metal oxides which are mainly divided into vanadium catalysts and non-vanadium catalysts two types. Vanadium-based catalysts use vanadium oxide with ideal lattice oxygen as the active component and SiO2, Al2O3, TiO2, etc., as the carriers [2,11–13]. SiO2, Al2O3, TiO2, etc., have certain Lewis acid and Bronsted acid sites that are beneficial to the adsorption of ammonia in the ammonia oxidation process. Oxygen is considered a typical Lewis base. Lewis acid site of the catalyst can increase the oxygen concentration on the surface of the catalyst, which is in favor of the formation of π complex reaction of the aromatic substrate on the surface of the catalyst and then result in further oxidation [14,15]. For vanadium catalysts, Das and Kar [16] after looking into the ammoxidation reaction of toluene discovered that the addition of Cr could reduce the bond energy of the V = O bond, thus facilitating the movement of surface oxygen and accelerating the redox cycle. Huang et al. [17] studied the ammoxidation of 2, 6-dichloro toluene, and found that the active components of the VCr/SiO2 catalyst were amorphous phase V2O5 and CrVO4. The addition of Cr can adjust the acidity and basicity of the catalyst. Xie et al. [18–20] on the study of o-xylene ammoxidation over VCr/SiO2 catalyst, concluded that V-Cr existed as vanadium pentavalent oxide and chromium trivalent oxide, respectively, and the addition of Cr could inhibit the formation of crystalline phase V2O5. In addition to V2O5 and CrVO4, there were also V2O5-x and Cr3+ x in the non-stoichiometric ratio of the supported V-Cr catalyst, which may lead to the occurrence of side reactions such as peroxide [21]. Recent studies have shown that the surface lattice oxygen migration rate of V-Cr-based catalysts is the key factor affecting the selectivity of aromatic nitrile, and the catalyst performance can be adjusted by adding different additives [22]. Martin et al. [2,23] found that alkali metals could change the structure and base property of vanadium-based catalysts, while B addition could improve the dispersion of active components. As far as Burkhardt et al. [24,25] were concerned, the addition of Fe3+ could enhance the oxidation and acidity of the catalyst. They suggested that the formation of Lewis acid centers depended on the Fe3+/Fe2+ equilibrium and that the formation of weak oxygen bonds caused the substrate to over-oxidize into HCN and CO2. However, the role of Fe3+ in the process of o-xylene ammoxidation has not been further explained. Therefore, this study attempt to study the relationship between the amount of Fe2O3 added in V-Cr based catalyst and the conversion and product selectivity of o-xylene ammoxidation, and further understand the mechanism of promoting activity by Fe2O3 addition with the help of correlation spectroscopic characterization. 2 Experimental procedure 2.1 Catalysts preparation The catalyst with Fe2O3 theoretical content of 1 wt% is taken as an example. 19.8 g of the formed SiO2 spheres were impregnated in the prepared Fe(NO3)3 solution with a mass fraction of 6.79% by equal volume impregnation method. After impregnation for 24 h, it was dried at 110 °C and calcined at 550 °C for 4 h in an air atmosphere to obtain SiO2 spheres with a content of 1.0 wt% Fe2O3. 1.431 g NH4VO3 was dissolved in water with oxalic acid to obtain 5 ml liquid A. Then liquid B was obtained by dissolving 3.507 g Cr(NO3)3 in 5 ml water. 0.06074 g phosphoric acid mixed with 0.2183 g (NH4)6Mo7O24 to obtain 5 ml liquid C. Finally, mixing the liquid A, B, and C under the condition of 70 °C water bath to get the liquid D. The formed SiO2 spheres made above were impregnated in liquid D by equal volume impregnation method for 24 h. Then we obtained the catalyst precursor of which active component contents was 10 wt% (mass fraction). Then they were dried at 110 °C and calcined at 550 °C for 4 h in an air atmosphere. In this way, we could obtain the catalyst with 10 wt% content of active species. In the same way to obtain the catalysts with theoretical Fe2O3 content of 0, 0.5 and 1.5 wt%. The prepared catalysts were labeled as FexVCrPMo with x values of 0, 0.5, 1, and 1.5 according to the added content of Fe2O3. 2.2 Catalyst characterization X-ray diffraction (XRD) was used to analyze the crystal structure and phase change of the catalyst by using a Japanese Rigaku Ultima-IV X-ray diffractometer under the Cu-Ka (λ = 0.54060) source radiation. The working voltage is 40 kV and the current is 30 mA. The scanning range is 5–90° and the scanning rate is 20°/min. BET surface area of the catalyst was measured by Micromeritics TriStar Ⅱ 3020 analyzer. High-purity N2 was used as an adsorption medium and liquid nitrogen was used to keep the environment at 77 K for adsorption. Before the test, the samples were vacuumed for 3 h at 300 °C. The specific surface test was calculated by the multilayer physical adsorption method (BET equation), and pore volume and pore diameter were calculated by the capillary coagulation adsorption curve method (BJH method). The acid property of the catalyst surface was tested by the MFTP3060 program temperature rising instrument by analyzing the NH3 desorption (NH3-TPD) on the catalyst surface. 100 mg 40–60-mesh sample was treated with 30 mL/min Ar at a rate of 10 °C/min from room temperature to 300 °C. After pretreatment at constant temperature for 1 h, it was cooled to 110 °C. The gas was switched to a 5%NH3-Ar mixture at a flow rate of 30 mL/min for 1 h adsorption. After adsorption was saturated, Ar passed at a 30 mL/min flow rate. When the chromatographic baseline was stable, the temperature was heated to 790 °C at the rate of 10 °C/min for desorption. The desorbed NH3 was detected online by TCD. NH3 absorbed infrared (NH3-IR) was used to analyze the adsorption of ammonia at the acid site on the catalyst surface by Thermo Fisher is-50 infrared spectrometer. The sample was pretreated in an Ar atmosphere at 300 °C for 1 h and then cooled down to 110 °C, then the 5%NH3-Ar mixture was added for ammonia adsorption. The air background of the ammonia-saturated sample was collected at room temperature and placed in the ATR detection tank to collect the spectrum 64 times, and the instrument resolution was 4 cm−1. At the same time, the H2-TPR test was conducted to explore the redox properties of the catalyst by the MFTP3060 programmed temperature system. 100 mg of 40–60-mesh sample was used to increase from room temperature to 300 °C at a rate of 10 °C/min in the Ar atmosphere with a flow rate of 30 mL/min. After pretreatment at a constant temperature for 1 h, the temperature was cooled down to 50 °C, and the gas was switched to 10%H2-Ar. After the chromatographic baseline was stabilized, Temperature programmed reduction was carried out at a rate of 10 °C/min up to 790 °C. The amount of hydrogen consumed in the reduction process was measured by TCD. After the temperature-programmed reduction, the temperature was cooled down to 400 °C, and air pulses were injected every 4 min to obtain pulse adsorption characterization. The oxygen consumption of the catalyst under reduction conditions was tested. The characterization of oxidation species on the catalyst surface was obtained by photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS). The photoelectron spectrometer type is Thermo Scientific ESCALAB Xi+, and the energy resolution of the insulation material is 0.68 eV. Electron paramagnetic resonance spectroscopy (EPR) was used to observe the valence state and oxygen vacancy of the catalyst. EPR spectrometer type is EMXplus-9.5/12, spectral resolution bit 1.5 μT. 2.3 Evaluation of catalytic performances A single-channel fixed bed intelligent evaluation device (Xiamen Better Work Intelligent Technology) was used for the ammonia oxidation reaction. The catalyst loading capacity is 5 g, the inner diameter of the reaction tube is 16 mm, the outer diameter is 20 mm, and the main pipe length is 60 mm. The upper and bottom of the catalyst bed are filled with appropriate quartz sand. Firstly, the temperature was heated to 400 °C at 3 °C/min in the air atmosphere, and then o-xylene (OPT) was injected into the reaction unit with an injection metering pump. Then ammonia gas was also injected. The reaction bed was heated and kept at 460 °C, while the o-xylene liquid space velocity was 0.08 h −1. V(OPT): V(NH3): V(air: O2) = 1:42:52. Finally, the reaction product and unreacted o-xylene were collected by ethylbenzene and analyzed by FID detector of the gas chromatograph. The gas components were directly entered into GC9160 gas chromatography for online PDI analysis. The cumulative reaction time of each evaluation was 8 h, and the analysis result was the average value. 3 Result and discussion 3.1 X-ray diffraction analysis of catalysts Fig. 2 shows the XRD patterns of FexVCrPMo catalysts with different Fe2O3 contents. From the spectral line, different FexVCrPMo catalysts mainly showed a wide peak near the diffraction Angle 2θ = 23°, which belonged to the characteristic peak of amorphous SiO2, and there was neither peak shape of vanadium and chromium oxide nor Fe2O3, This indicates that there was no obvious crystal phase of vanadium or chromium oxide and Fe2O3. Both vanadium and chromium species and Fe2O3 existed on the surface of the SiO2 carrier in the form of the amorphous phase or dispersed uniformly on the surface of the SiO2 carrier, indicating that the addition of Fe2O3 had no obvious effect on the crystal structure of the catalyst. 3.2 BET surface area Fig. 3 and Table 1 respectively show the N2 adsorption and desorption curves and physical properties of the FexVCrPMo catalyst. As can be seen from Fig. 3, the N2 adsorption and desorption curve of the FexVCrPMo catalyst didn't change with the addition of Fe2O3, and still maintained a type IV isotherm, with retardation loop appearing at P/P0 = 0.6 to P/P0 = 0.9, indicating that Fe2O3 catalyst still maintained a mesoporous structure with wide pore diameter distribution. As shown in Table 1, BET surface area, pore volume and pore diameter of FexVCrPMo catalysts increased first and then decreased, but the difference was not significant. This showed that SiO2 carrier preferentially supports an appropriate amount of Fe2O3, and Fe2O3 interacted with the SiO2 carrier in the process of heat treatment, which had a certain modification and extension effect on the pores of the SiO2 carrier. However, the addition of too much Fe2O3 may block some pores of the SiO2 carrier, resulting in the reduction of BET surface area and pore volume. 3.3 Characterization of NH3-TPD and NH3-IR of catalysts Fig. 4 shows the NH3-TPD spectra of the FexVCrPMo catalyst with different Fe2O3 content. It could be seen that FexVCrPMo catalysts with different Fe2O3 content had little difference in the corresponding spectral line peak pattern, but the peak location was different, indicating that there were certain differences in the acid center of different FexVCrPMo catalysts. A relatively obvious low-temperature desorption peak appears in the 100–350 °C temperature region, which belonged to the desorption peak of NH3 corresponding to the weak acid center. Table 1 showed that as the Fe2O3 content increased, the weak acidity values within the temperature range of 110 °C to 270 °C increased. With the increase of Fe2O3 content, the low-temperature desorption peak tended to shift to the high-temperature direction, manifesting that the strength of the acid center was enhanced. At the same time, it could be seen that there was an insignificant NH3 desorption peak belonging to the middle temperature in the temperature region of 350–550 °C. As the content of Fe2O3 increased, the medium acid sites became stronger slightly. However, as the content of Fe2O3 increased to 1 wt%, the strength of medium acid sites declined. When the content was up to 1.5 wt%, medium acid sites moved to the low temperature which indicated that the excess loading of Fe2O3 could decline the acidity of medium acid sites on catalysts. For the ammoniation process, NH3 needs to be adsorbed on the surface of the catalyst, and the adsorption amount and the strength of the acid center can directly affect the reaction rate. Fig. 5 shows the NH3-IR spectra of the FexVCrPMo catalyst with different Fe2O3 content. It showed that 464, 1078 and 963 cm−1 on the spectrum referred to the vibration of Cr-O, V = O, and Mo-O respectively, and 799 and 1205 cm−1 referred to the absorption peaks of Si-O-Si and O-Si-O in the carrier. 1631 cm−1 belonged to the HO-H bending vibration peak of adsorbed water, and the wide peak of 3500 cm−1 might include the antisymmetric stretching vibration peak of Si-OH, V-OH, and water OH [26–28]. As the content of Fe2O3 increased, the peak areas 1078cm−1 in were corresponding to 9.138, 11.155, 10.001, and 10.519 respectively. By comparing the peak area of spectral lines, it could be seen that compared with the Fe0VCrPMo catalyst, the vibration peak of 1078 cm−1 belonging to V = O (including V5+=O and V4+=O) on the spectral line corresponding to FexVCrPMo catalyst with Fe2O3 was enhanced to a certain extent, indicating that the addition of Fe2O3 had an effect on the surface V = O compounds (including V5+ = O and V4+ = O). Among them, the Fe0.5VCrPMo catalyst was the most obvious. Going one step further, the author magnified the spectral peaks at 1447 and 3500 cm−1, corresponding to Figs. 5-a and 6 respectively. In Fig. 5-a, the spectral peak at 1447 cm−1 could be attributed to the absorption spectral peak of NH4 + generated by the interaction of NH3 with H + on the catalyst surface, representing the strength of the Bronsted acid site on the catalyst surface. The area of each peak was corresponding to 0.02323, 0.04817, 0.04232, and 0.04572 respectively, as the content of Fe2O3 went up. The Bronsted acid strength of the catalyst with Fe2O3 increased slightly, but not obviously. As could be seen from the spectral lines in Fig. 6, the broad peak of 3500 cm−1 was the superimposed shoulder peak. Among them, the peak at 3234 cm−1 could be attributed to the spectral peak of NH3 complexing with the Lewis acid site with Lone Pair-Electrons, which represents the strength of the Lewis acid site on the catalyst surface [26–28]. With the increase of Fe2O3, the number of Lewis acid sites on the catalyst surface increased first and then decreased, while Fe0.5VCrPMo and Fe1.0VCrPMo catalysts had more Lewis acid sites. The spectral peak at 3443 cm−1 in the figure could be attributed to the antisymmetric stretching vibration peak of the OH of Si-OH and H2O. And the surface hydroxyl group (-OH) of Si-OH had the characteristics of the Lewis base [26–28]. Similarly, with the increase of Fe2O3, the strength of the Lewis base increased first and then decreased. It's worth noting that the vibration of the peak belonging to V-OH at 3600 cm−1 was enhanced to a certain extent, which was easy to form a V-O-V species with oxidation activity in the reaction process. Meanwhile, the decrease of V-OH had a certain effect on the deactivation of the catalyst [29]. 3.4 X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy Fig. 7 shows the XPS spectra of V2p in V-Cr/SiO2 catalysts with different Fe2O3 contents. As can be seen from the spectrum lines of the Fe0VCrPMo/SiO2 catalyst in Fig. 7, the spectrum peak with binding energy at 516.78 ev could be considered as V2p3/2, while the peak with binding energy at 523.84 eV could be considered as V2p1/2 [30]. With the increase of Fe2O3 content, the binding energy of V2p tended to shift to low energy. According to the further peak fitting of V2p3/2, the two peaks of the binding energy of 516.57 ev and 516.85 eV in the spectral lines of Fe0VCrPMo/SiO2 catalyst could be corresponding to V4+ and V5+ oxides respectively [30]. At the same time, it was easy to find that as the Fe2O3 content went up, different valence states and contents of V different oxides gradually changed. The spectral lines of Fe1VCrPMo/SiO2 and Fe1.5VCrPMo/SiO2 catalysts appeared V3+ oxides at BE=515.47 ev and 515.63 ev, respectively, which reduced the average oxidation state of vanadium oxide. Combined with the different peak area of V2p3/2 peak fitting analysis on catalysts with different Fe2O3 contents listed in Table 2 , the content variation trends of different valence of V could be found. It could be inferred that the doping of Fe3+ with small radius into V2O5 lattice was conducive to the movement of vanadium oxide lattice oxygen, promoting the transition from high state to low state, and might form the off-stoichiometry V2O5-x complex oxides. The results showed that Fe2O3 doping made vanadium oxide form oxygen vacancies more easily, which accelerated the liquidity of lattice oxygen in the catalyst and improved the electron transfer ability of the catalysts [31]. This result was equal to the findings of Kuang et al. [32]. They found that the strong interaction between cobalt, vanadium, and iron ions (partial electron transfer from Co2+/Fe3+ to V5+) caused the electron loss of Co ions and Fe ions, resulting in the transition of vanadium from high coordination to low coordination, and causing the surface defects and unsaturated sites to appear. Thus, the exposure of the active sites of the catalysts was promoted and the conductivity of the catalyst was improved. So, the adsorption of nucleophilic groups on the surface of the catalyst was facilitated. According to the MARS-Van Krevelen mechanism, the reaction was characterized by a reversible V5+/V4+ redox cycle, which required not only a certain number of V = O compounds (including V5+ = O and V4+ = O) on the catalyst surface but also a suitable V +4/V +5 ratio. The characterization of NH3-IR indicated that the addition of Fe2O3 was beneficial to the increase of V = O compounds (including V5+=O and V4+=O) in the catalyst, among which Fe0.5VCrPMo catalyst was more obvious. According to the V +4/V +5 ratios of different catalysts listed in Table 2, the V +4/V +5 ratio of the Fe0.5VCrPMo/SiO2 catalyst was close to 1, while Fe1.5VCrPMo/SiO2 catalyst had a larger V +4/V +5 ratio, which may affect the oxidation–reduction performance of the catalyst [33,34]. The peak area of V2p3/2 of the catalyst with different Fe2O3 content was further calculated by curve-fitting, in which the peak area represented the amount of V content on the catalyst surface, and the calculation results were shown in Table 3 . Table 3 showed that adding an appropriate amount of Fe2O3 loading was beneficial to the dispersion of vanadium oxides on the catalyst surface and increased the number of surface active vanadium centers. However, excessive Fe2O3 loading decreased the content of vanadium species on the surface, which may be that excessive Fe2O3 promoted the migration of vanadium oxides on the surface to the catalyst body phase or Fe2O3-covered vanadium oxides on the surface. Fig. 8 shows the XPS spectra of O1s of the FexVCrPMo catalyst with different Fe2O3 contents. It was generally believed that the BE values of 529.5, 531.5 and 532.3 eV in the spectral line could respectively refer to the XPS peaks corresponding to Oa, Ob, and Oc, which could be recognized as the lattice oxygen on the catalyst surface [22,35,36], the chemically adsorbed oxygen species on the surface oxygen vacancy and the hydroxyl oxygen on the SiO2 carrier [37]. In Fig. 8, with the addition of Fe2O3, the peak area of lattice oxygen Oa attributed to metal oxides on the catalyst surface increased slightly, but the change was not obvious, and only the peak area of O1s of Fe1.5VCrPMo catalyst decreased significantly. It could be further seen that the order of the peak area of oxygen adsorbed on the catalyst surface was: Fe0. 5VCrPMo > Fe1. 0VCrPMo > Fe0VCrPMo > Fe1.5VCrPMo（Table 4 ). At the same time, chemisorbed oxygen at oxygen vacancy could stabilize the action of oxygen vacancy, and abundant oxygen vacancy could enhance the electron conductance and liquidity of the catalyst. In particular, the vacancy defects in VOx gave it half metallicity that promoted the adsorption of oxygen in the gas phase and enhanced the performance of hydrogen evolution and oxygen reduction, which made the oxygen in the catalyst phase continue to move to the surface of the catalyst and became O2− with catalytic activity [34]. At the same time, Fe2O3 belonged to the n-Type semiconductor, and the addition of Fe2O3 could increase the electron density in the catalyst, which was also conducive to the stable existence of O2−. It is indicated that Fe2O3 could promote the formation of oxygen vacancies in the FexVCrPMo catalysts and the formation of chemisorbed oxygen at surface oxygen vacancies, which was favorable to the movement of lattice oxygen. Among them, the Fe0.5VCrPMo catalyst had the most lattice oxygen vacancies and adsorbed oxygen. The vanadium species might be transferred to the catalyst phase of Fe1.5VCrPMo catalyst, thus, the surface SiO2 is gradually exposed and the catalyst surface area decreased along with the increase of the hydroxyl oxygen on the SiO2 carrier while the catalyst oxygen vacancies and surface chemical adsorbed oxygen species decreased. In addition, the BE value in the XPS spectrum of O1s of metal oxides could be used to compare the strength of the base property. The lower the BE value was the stronger the base site was [38]. In the XPS spectral line of FexVCrPMo catalysts, the BE value corresponding to O1s decreased first and then increased, indicating that the corresponding base properties of FexVCrPMo catalysts increased first and then decreased. Combined with the NH3-TPD diagram in Fig. 3, it showed that the addition of Fe2O3 could change the acid-base properties of V-Cr based catalysts at the same time. The increase in BE value of the Fe1.5VCrPMo catalyst was mainly related to the increase of SiO2 on the surface, which mainly reflected the acidity of the support. The BET characterization results showed that this might be related to the decrease of the specific surface area of the catalyst, resulting in the decrease of the content of active components on the surface of the support. 3.5 EPR characterization of catalysts Currently, the EPR technique can be used to detect unpaired electrons and metal oxide lattice oxygen sites [39]. Fig.9 shows the EPR spectra of V-Cr/SiO2 catalysts with different Fe2O3 contents. The V5+ valence electron has no single electron and no paramagnetic effect, so it can't be detected in EPR. Generally, the peak of the EPR spectrum at g = 1.96 and g = 2.000 could refer to the V4+ species and the oxygen vacancy, respectively [40]. The symmetric EPR peak near g = 1.9679 in the spectral line could be attributed to the superposition of EPR peaks of V4+ species and the oxygen vacancy. It could be seen that with the increase of Fe2O3 content, the peak width of g = 1.9679 spectral line increased obviously, and the peak intensity obviously increased first and then decreases. The results of EPR characterization were basically consistent with those of XPS characterization, indicating that the addition of Fe2O3 content was beneficial to the improvement of V4+ species and the oxygen vacancy content, which was conducive to the oxidation–reduction process. 3.6 Redox property test of catalysts Fig. 10 shows the H2-TPR spectra of FexVCrPMo catalysts with different Fe2O3 contents. Generally speaking, pure V2O5 reduction peaks of the three reduction processes corresponding to V2O5→1/3V6O13→2VO2→V2O3 are located at 632, 683 and 833 °C respectively [41,42]. The addition of Cr2O3 reduced the activation energy required for the reduction of V2O5 in the catalyst. Therefore, the hydrogen consumption peak corresponding to the reduction process of V5+→V3+ and Cr6+ → Cr3+ characterized by TPR in the V-Cr catalyst was mainly concentrated in the temperature range of 400–800 °C [43]. The H2 consumption amount for various FexVCrPMo catalysts at the temperature range from 400 to 750 °C indicated a gradual increase in reduction areas as the Fe2O3 content increased which could be seen in Table 1. In the process of ammoxidation reaction, V4+ is reduced to V3+ and V5+ is reduced to V4+. Theoretically, both the V5+/V4+ and V4+/V3+ redox pairs will participate in the ammoxidation reaction, but at the reaction temperature of 400–500 °C, it should be easier to carry out the V5+/V4+ redox cycle. Fig. 10 showed that the spectral lines of the Fe0VCrPMo catalyst only had an overlapping single peak in the temperature range of 400–700 °C. With the increase of Fe2O3 content, the overlapping single peak was separated, and three overlapping shoulder peaks were formed eventually, indicating that the addition of Fe2O3 changed the interaction between chrome-vanadium species and the carrier, thus affecting the reduction performance of vanadium-chromium oxides. With the increase of Fe2O3, some VOx reduction peaks gradually moved towards low temperature, indicating that the addition of Fe2O3 was conducive to the removal of lattice oxygen of vanadium oxide, that is, to enhance the liquidity of lattice oxygen. It could also be seen that with the increase of Fe2O3, the reduction temperature of Cr6+ also moved to a low temperature and the peak area increased slightly, indicating that the introduction of iron ions promoted the separation of the reduction peak of chromium oxides from that of vanadium oxides, and Cr6+ in the catalyst was more easily reduced to Cr3+ and Cr3+ x [20,27]. This result further showed that the addition of Fe2O3 changed the interaction between chromium and vanadium, facilitated the lattice oxygen movement and electron acquisition ability of vanadium and chromium oxides, and improved the reduction performance of vanadium and chromium oxides. To further understand the redox performance of the reduced catalyst in which lattice oxygen was removed in the reduction process, the air pulse oxidation test was carried out on the reduced catalyst. Combined with the XPS characterization results of FexVCrPMo catalysts corresponding to O1s in Fig. 8, the movement performance of gas phase oxygen into the lattice oxygen vacancy and the chemisorption performance of oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface was verified. Fig. 11 showed the corresponding air pulse spectra of FexVCrPMo catalysts with different Fe2O3 contents. By comparing the pulse peak area, it could be seen that the peak area of the fifth and sixth air pulse peaks of different catalysts was practically unchanged, and it was considered that the lattice oxygen vacancy and surface oxygen absorption site of the catalyst were almost saturated after the fifth air pulse. Therefore, it was assumed that the peak area of the fifth pulse peak was the reference area, and the area ratio of the first four pulse peaks to the fifth pulse peak was calculated respectively as the relative saturation value. The relative saturation value of the fifth pulse peak is 1.0, and the calculation results were shown in Table 5 . The relative oxygen consumption value of each pulse was calculated by the same method, and the trend graph of the relative oxygen consumption value of successive pulses was listed, as shown in Fig. 11. The total relative oxygen consumption of FexVCrPMo was calculated by adding the relative oxygen consumption values of the first four times, as shown in Table 6 . By comparing the calculation results of the first pulse peak in Table 5 and Fig. 12 , it could be seen that the reoxidation and oxygen adsorption properties of the reduced FexVCrPMo catalyst were significantly improved when Fe2O3 is added, and the reoxidation and oxygen adsorption rates were enhanced with the increase of Fe2O3 addition, Fe1. 5VCrPMo > Fe1. 0VCrPMo > Fe0. 5VCrPMo > Fe0VCrPMo. Further, the calculation results in Table 6, showed that the order of relative oxygen consumption of catalysts with different Fe2O3 content was as follows: Fe1. 0VCrPMo > Fe0. 5VCrPMo > Fe0VCrPMo > Fe1.5VCrPMo, indicating that the number of lattice oxygen vacancies in reduced the FexVCrPMo catalyst increased with the addition of Fe2O3, but the number of lattice oxygen vacancies in the catalyst decreased with the addition of excessive Fe2O3. Combined with the BET characterization results, this might be related to the reduction of the specific surface area of the Fe1.5VCrPMo catalyst, resulting in a decrease in the number of lattice oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface. Combined with the characterization of H2-TPR and the results of the air pulse oxidation test, it was shown that the amount of lattice oxygen vacancies in the FexVCrPMo catalyst could be improved by adding Fe2O3, to improve the liquidity of lattice oxygen in the catalyst and the oxidation–reduction reaction performance was enhanced. 3.7 Catalytic performance Table 7 lists the evaluation results of o-xylene ammoxidation over FexVCrPMo catalysts with different Fe3O2 content. As could be seen from Table 7, the distribution of ammoxidation products in this experiment was consistent with the possible road map of the o-xylene ammoxidation reaction in Fig. 1 [2]. It was worth noting that no phthalic diamide was detected in the product, which might be related to the instability of phthalic diamide under high temperature and water vapor conditions which made it easy to deaminize and decompose into phthalimide. In particular, the presence of acid or base is more likely to promote the decomposition of phthalic diamide into phthalimide [2]. As could be seen from Table 7, with the increase of Fe2O3 content, the conversion of o-xylene corresponding to different FexVCrPMo catalysts increased first and then decreased. The conversion of o-xylene is in the following order: Fe0. 5VCrPMo > Fe1. 0VCrPMo > Fe1. 5VCrPMo > Fe0VCrPMo, where the conversion of o-xylene corresponding to Fe0.5VCrPMo catalyst was close to 95%, indicating that the addition of Fe2O3 could improve the conversion of o-xylene. Related studies [44]suggested that vanadium-catalyzed ammoxidation followed the Mars-Van Krevelene mechanism, which was characterized by a reversible V5+/V4+ oxidation–reduction cycle. Among them, both V = O and the dual-coordinated V-O-V might be involved in the oxidation process, and the V = O site was the main catalytic activity center. V = O activated NH3, which was fractured and regenerated through the reoxidation process, which solved the competitive adsorption of NH3 and O2 at the same active site. The mechanism of ammoxidation of toluene [10] discovered that V4+ was the active site of ammoxidation, and V = O was the active center to activate substrate molecules for dehydrogenation and to insert the N. After the product benzonitrile was removed from the active site, oxygen vacancies were formed on the catalyst surface. Lattice oxygen could be regenerated by further oxidation. The selective oxidation activity of the vanadium catalyst depended on the difficulty of removing O by the V = O bond and the speed of surface oxygen activation. O2 was adsorbed on the surface of the catalyst, and through dynamic equilibrium formed O2−, which was transferred to the catalyst lattice and regenerated lattice oxygen to participate in selective oxidation. The results of the H2-TPR characterization and air pulse oxidation test showed that the lattice oxygen liquidity and oxidation–reduction performance of FexVCrPMo catalysts could be improved by adding Fe2O3. The XPS and EPR characterization of the catalyst also indicated that the addition of Fe2O3 was beneficial to improve the adsorption of oxygen corresponding to V4+ species and oxygen vacancies, which were conducive to the oxidation–reduction process. However, as the content of Fe2O3 keeping to increase, the adsorption oxygen corresponding to V4+ species and oxygen vacancies decreased, which was not good for the oxidation–reduction process. It could be reasonably explained that the conversion of o-xylene was in the following order: Fe0. 5VCrPMo > Fe1. 0VCrPMo > Fe1. 5VCrPMo > Fe0VCrPMo. Among them, Fe0.5VCrPMo catalyst had the highest V4+ species, the adsorption oxygen corresponding to oxygen vacancies, and a reasonable V +4/V +5 ratio, so Fe0.5VCrPMo catalyst had the highest conversion. According to the characterization results of NH3-TPD, the addition of Fe2O3 could improve the acid strength of the catalyst acid center, which was beneficial to improve the adsorption of NH3 on the catalyst surface, Meanwhile, the adsorption amount of NH3 and the strength of the acid center could directly affect the reaction rate. Centi et al. [45] considered that there was competition between ammonia and substrate for obtaining lattice oxygen on the catalyst surface. The ammonia oxidation reaction of propane on the V-Sb-O catalyst was more likely to occur than that of the substrate. When the amount of ammonia adsorbed on the surface was too much, the oxidation activity of the catalyst would be reduced, and the conversion of raw material would be reduced. However, too little ammonia adsorbed would lead to an insufficient supply of N-inserted species, and the selectivity of aromatic nitrile would be reduced. Therefore, the surface of the catalyst requires a reasonable amount of oxygen adsorption, or acid strength, which further explained the highest conversion of Fe0.5VCrPMo catalyst. As shown in Table 7, with the increase of Fe2O3 content, the selectivity of reaction products varied with different FexVCrPMo catalysts. Compared with Fe0VCrPMo catalyst, Fe0.5VCrPMo catalyst, Fe1.0VCrPMo catalyst, and Fe1.5VCrPMo catalyst, the selectivity of phthalonitrile corresponding to Fe0VCrPMo catalyst decreased slightly, which was related to the increase of the selectivity of methylbenzenitrile and phthalimide catalyst. With the increase of Fe2O3 content, the selectivity of the FexVCrPMo catalyst increased first and then decreased. The presence of water vapor in the reaction system could greatly promote the formation of phthalimide (Step 4) through an amide intermediate by phthalonitrile (Step 3) [2]. Water vapor was the product of the ammoxidation of o-xylene. The higher the conversion, the higher the concentration of water vapor generated in the reaction system, which was in favor of the formation of phthalimide. The order of conversion of FexVCrPMo catalysts for o-xylene ammoxidation was consistent with the selectivity change law of the FexVCrPMo catalyst for phthalimide. It was worth noting that the total selectivity of the ammoxidation products, corresponding to FexVCrPMo catalyst, tolunitrile, phthalonitrile, and phthalimide increased first and then decreased with the increase of Fe2O3 content, among which Fe0.5VCrPMo had the highest total selectivity and the highest yield of phthalonitrile. This result was related to the improvement of the ammoxidation conversion of o-xylene. Compared with Fe0VCrPMo, Fe0.5VCrPMo, Fe1.0VCrPMo, and Fe1.5VCrPMo, the selectivity of tolunitrile was slightly improved. This result was also related to the increase in conversion after the addition of Fe2O3, and a new equilibrium was formed in the three parallel reactions of demethylation, oxidation, and ammoxidation. It could be seen from the possible road map of o-xylene ammoxidation in Fig. 1 [2], o-xylene could be obtained by one-step ammoxidation to phthalonitrile, or by two-step ammoxidation to the intermediate product tolunitrile. Among them, the intermediate tolunitrile might be further oxidized to phthalimide and demethylated to benzonitrile. According to the results in Table 6, on the one hand, the selectivity of phthalimide might be closely related to the existence of water vapor in the reaction system to cause hydrolysis and deamination of phthalonitrile. On the other hand, benzonitrile competed with the formation of phthalimide, which was favored by the presence of V5+ [2]. Compared with the Fe0VCrPMo catalyst, the proportion of V5+ in the Fe0.5VCrPMo catalyst increased, which was conducive to the formation of phthalimide. With the increase of Fe2O3 content, the oxidation state of V migrated to a lower price, V5+ decreased gradually, and the oxidation reaction of tolunitrile to phthalimide weakened. The benzonitrile selectivity of the FexVCrPMo catalyst decreased first and then increased with the increase of Fe2O3 content, and the selectivity corresponding to Fe0.5VCrPMo was the lowest.At the same time, with the increase of Fe2O3 content, the total selectivity of tolunitrile and benzonitrile decreased first and then increased. This indicates that the addition of too much Fe2O3 made the formation of intermediate product tolunitrile more prominent, especially making the further demethylation of tolunitrile to benzonitrile easier. In the ammoxidation of o-xylene, the acidity of the catalyst had a certain effect on the selectivity of phthalonitrile. If the acidity was too weak, the adsorption energy of the catalyst for ammonia gas is insufficient, gaseous ammonia could not be effectively adsorbed and activated in ammonia oxidation to become the insertion species of N, and the selectivity of phthalonitrile decreased accordingly. If the acid is too strong, the nitrile generated was difficult to desorption [25]. Tolunitrile was easily further demethylated to form the byproduct benzonitrile. The sequence of the acid strength of the FexVCrPMo catalyst given by NH3-TPD indicated that the increase of Fe2O3 content increased the selectivity of benzonitrile. As could be seen from Table 6, with the increase of Fe2O3 content, the selectivity of CO and CO2 (collectively called COX) of excessive oxidation products in the process of ammoxidation gradually decreased, indicating that the addition of Fe2O3 could inhibit excessive oxidation. Guseinov et al. [46] pointed out that when a large amount of ammonia was adsorbed on the surface of the catalyst, the adsorbed oxygen would be blocked, to avoid deep oxidation to produce excessive COx, and the selectivity of the target product was improved. According to the characterization results of NH3-TPD, the addition of Fe2O3 could improve the acid strength of the acidic center of the catalyst, which was conducive to the adsorption of NH3 on the surface of the catalyst. This result was consistent with the conclusion of Guseinov et al. [46]. According to the XPS characterization results, Fe2O3 doped into V2O5 lattice was conducive to the movement of vanadium oxide lattice oxygen, promoting the transition from the high state to low state, and high state V oxide had high oxidation ability, which was easy to cause the deep oxidation of carbon and oxygen compounds in the system. On the other hand, with the increase of Fe2O3 content, the average valence state of V oxide in FexVCrPMo catalyst decreased, and oxygen bond energy of V oxide increased, which could slow down the oxygen evolution rate and inhibit the complete oxidation of organic molecules, which was consistent with the gradual decrease of the selectivity of excessive oxidation products COX. 4 Conclusion The addition of Fe2O3 on V-Cr based catalysts is beneficial to the formation of oxygen vacancies and chemisorbed oxygen on surface oxygen vacancies, thus promoting the formation of V = O and V-O-V with catalytic activity, and obtaining reasonable V5+/V4+ values. Fe2O3 can regulate the redox performance of the catalyst and promote the V5+/V4+ redox cycle. At the same time, Fe2O3 can increase the acidic site and basic site on the catalyst surface, thus affecting the ammonia adsorption on the catalyst surface. These characteristics and correlations will contribute to the development of catalysts with better performance in the future. The results show that Fe2O3 can promote the ammoxidation of o-xylene with a V-Cr catalyst. The conversion of o-xylene is in the order of Fe0. 5VCrPMo > Fe1. 0VCrPMo > Fe1. 5VCrPMo > Fe0VCrPMo. The conversion of o-xylene is close to 95% for Fe0.5VCrPMo catalyst with 0.5% Fe2O3. However, due to the steric effect of o-xylene and other factors, etc., the selectivity of the product has not reached the ideal goal, so the catalyst with better catalytic activity and higher selectivity is still to be developed. coredata.dc:description: A series of V-Cr-based catalysts with different Fe2O3 contents were prepared for o-xylene ammoxidation and their catalytic property was studied. The evaluation results showed that the appropriate Fe2O3 addition enhanced catalytic performance, and the best addition mass fraction was 0.5%. The conversion of o-xylene ammoxidation on the catalysts with different Fe2O3 contents increased from 53.8% to 94.7%, and the yield of the target product increased from 32.7% to 53.0%. It was found that the addition of Fe2O3 can change the physical properties and acid-base properties of the catalyst. An appropriate amount of Fe2O3 not only improved the amount of lattice oxygen vacancies in the catalyst and changed the adsorbed oxygen on the surface, but also adjusted the V +4 /V +5 ratio of active oxide V=O, which is conducive to the oxidation–reduction process, thus improving the performance of the catalyst.
coredata.dc:title: The effect of Fe2O3 promotion on the ammoxidation of o-xylene with V-Cr-based catalyst
